captions.text:
The clip we're doing now is on teaching your
budgie to talk. This is a very difficult thing,

and I wouldn't get a budgie, or many parakeets
with the goal of teaching them to talk, because

it might not happen. But I don't want to say
it doesn't, especially if you invest the effort,

you can get a few phrases. But some of these
birds have been known to be able to say a

hundred, a hundred and fifty phrases, almost
as many as an African Grey. The big difference

between parakeets talking and many of the
older or bigger parrot species is that these

guys do truly parrot what they talk. They
don't know what they're saying. They just

say it because they're trying to be part of
their flock, and so they're trying to make

the same noises of their flock. What's very
important with these guys is that you be very

consistent. I'm just calling this bird Bob.
You say, "Hi Bob, what are you doing, Bob?

You a good bird, Bob?". Say the same things
over and over. Try and use exact same tone,

and say it over and over and over again. Tell
them, whether it's "pretty bird", or "I love

you", or the same thing. Just, "I love you,
I love you". So you'll say it over and over

again and you'll find after a, it could take
two to four weeks, with a younger bird it

could take up to a few months for them to
really start talking, but you'll start hearing

that exact same tone, that exact same inflection
in their voice. At first it'll just sound

like tone and inflection, and as they get
better and better at copying those sounds,

they'll start sounding more and more clear,
like words and not just repeating your tone

and inflection. They're actually pretty talented
talkers, as well, so if it's a man's voice

it will very clearly be a man's voice. If
it's a child's voice, it's also very clearly

a child's voice. They'll pick up other sounds
in the household as well. Not so much microwave

beeps, but sometimes the sound of trickling
water or a certain sound a door makes when

it opens, the creaking in and out. If you
want a budgie also that talks, it's very important

that actually you only have one budgie. If
you have two budgies, or more, it's very,

very unlikely you're going to be able to teach
that parakeet to talk. Mostly just because

it's easier for them to mock their parakeet
friends than it is to try and replicate human

speech. So if you're it's only other source
of sounds to try and copy, you're going to

get a lot better response for, from your bird,
in trying to learn to talk. So just work with

them everyday. Be very consistent about the
phrases that you want to say, and spend a

lot of time with them. And just naturally,
your bird will start picking up little tones

and phrases that you happen to say to your
bird everyday.

title: Caring for Parakeets : Teaching a Parakeet to Talk

getting another budgie a viable way of helping the new one learn to talk? I 
know if you get them both at the same time they'll never learn to talk, but 
will one take cues from the other? Or will the first one forsake speech in 
exchange for chirping again?﻿

comments.author: giraffies g

comments.text:
That makes sense. Wish it were possible to teach them in mass, but I guess 
the birds' personal identification with their flock (and thus, the source 
of their mimicry) makes it really hard to do that.
comments.author: Liuhuayue

comments.text:
+Liuhuayue Yep , he's got his own cage and rarely interacts with his 
parents.

Separating them has benefits.It allows for easier handling , cleaning , it 
is OBLIGATORY if you plan on taming and teaching to speak , it prevents 
crowding , older keets picking on young ones , etc.
comments.author: MrPedala94

comments.text:
Nice, MrPedala94! Did you keep him in his own enclosure/ cage away from 
other parakeets?
comments.author: Liuhuayue

comments.text:
+Liuhuayue There's no harm in exposing him to your voice.I started talking 
to mine when he was ~1.5 months old and now he won't shut up :D.
comments.author: MrPedala94

comments.text:
Yeah, I would agree, for the young budgies' safety, anyway. I guess it's 
not too early to start exposing them to human speech, though.
comments.author: Liuhuayue

comments.text:
+Liuhuayue Well it depends.Now that i've taken a closer look , this budgie 
is AT MOST 1 month old.Normally after 1 month , they can exit their nestbox 
on their own.
After 1 month , they are 95% autonomous(they just need to be shown where 
their food and water is ).
I would say it is best to refrain from "handling" a budgie until he has 
"come of age" so to speak.Only take him out if his nextbox needs cleaning 
and then only for a few minutes.
comments.author: MrPedala94

comments.text:
That's what I was thinking as an alternative to having some sort of health 
condition. It comes off strange-looking in the video, though. 1 month is 
pretty young to be handling young budgies, though, isn't it?
comments.author: Liuhuayue

comments.text: it is quite young.~1 month old

comments.text:
To tell if your budgie is a male/female look at the ceres (nostrils above 
beak). If they are a light brown or darker brown, its a female, females 
tend to be a lot more snappy and 'bitchy'. Males, most people find, are 
easier to teach and have light blue ceres or royal blue when they are ready 
to breed :)
comments.author: erin456723

comments.text:
Having two ore more budgies mean you cant teach them talk is false. You can 
teach your budgies to talk, but you have to separate them out and spend 
time with each one. This is a lot more time consuming , of course, than 
teaching just one budgie to talk. There's a bird owner who has several 
budgies that can talk and they all share the same room.
